facts: Cats have over 30 muscles in each ear, allowing them to rotate their ears 180 degrees.
A cat's purr vibrates at a frequency that can promote bone healing and reduce pain.
Cats spend 70% of their lives sleeping, which means a 9-year-old cat has been awake for only 3 years.
A group of cats is called a clowder, while a group of kittens is called a kindle.
Cats have a third eyelid called the nictitating membrane that helps protect and moisten their eyes.
The ridged pattern on a cat's nose is as unique as a human fingerprint.
Cats can jump up to six times their body length in a single bound.
Ancient Egyptians would shave their eyebrows as a sign of mourning when their cat died.
A cat's brain is 90% similar to a human brain, more similar than a dog's brain.
Cats have scent glands in their cheeks, paws, and flanks, which is why they rub against things.
The world's longest cat measured 48.5 inches from nose to tail tip.
Cats can rotate their whiskers forward to detect prey or backward to avoid damage.
A cat's heart beats nearly twice as fast as a human heart, at 110 to 140 beats per minute.
Cats have only 473 taste buds compared to humans who have 9,000.
The technical term for a cat's hairball is a bezoar.
Cats can make over 100 different vocal sounds, while dogs can only make about 10.
A cat's flexible spine allows them to twist their body while falling to land on their feet.
Cats conserve energy by sleeping more than most mammals, especially as they age.
The oldest known pet cat existed 9,500 years ago in Cyprus.
Cats have a reflective layer behind their retinas called tapetum lucidum that enhances night vision.
